text: So, hello.

I'd like to thank the organizers
for inviting me to be here.
I am just delighted to learn
from all of you who study organizations.
I'm a legal scholar, so I study the law,
in particular anti-discrimination law,

and especially with respect
to gender and sexuality.
So I have more to say today about the law,
but I also have a few things
that I'd like to say about organizations.
I've titled my presentation,

"A Right to Non-Binary
Gender, question mark,"

because I want to discuss
whether there is any such right
in the United States today,

and in keeping with the
theme of this conference,
whether the master's tools can be used
to promote any such right.

But before going farther,
I want to clarify

what I mean by a right
to non-binary gender.
I want to start by defining a related term

which we just heard about,
which is transgender.

I use the term transgender
to mean a person

who does not currently identify
with the gender associated

with the sex that they
were assigned at birth.
So that includes transgender men,

and transgender women,
like Christine Jorgenson,
who we just heard about.

Very often, transgender men and
women bring legal challenges
to institutions that refuse to count them
as real men or real women.
By non-binary, I mean something else.

I mean a person who does
not identify exclusively
as a man or a woman, a boy or a girl.
Non-binary is not a single identity,

it's a label for a large
number of identities.

Some people identify
themselves as agender,
gender queer, bigender, many others.

By non-binary, I mean
to include all of them.

Non-binary individuals
often bring legal challenges

to unnecessary practices
of sex segregation,

practices that divide us
into male and female groups.
To give you an example,

there's a group of non-binary
New Yorkers right now

who are suing New York
state welfare agencies
over the requirement that everybody
who wants to apply for welfare benefits
needs to check the M or the F box,

even though the benefits
have nothing to do
with gender or sex.

I'm particularly interested
in policy projects

that attempt to eliminate
unnecessary sex distinctions,
or when that's not possible,
add options other than male and female.

There are three questions
I want to address today.

First, is there a right to
non-binary gender in the US?

The short answer is, in some
places yes and to some extents,
but in other places, flat out no.

My second question then
is, will courts protect
the right to non-binary gender,
or are courts master's tools?
And my third question is,

what about pressure from LGBTQ
friendly corporate America?
I'm not terribly optimistic
about either courts or big business,

but I'm not ready to
give up on them either.
So my first question:

is there a right to
non-binary gender in the US?
Well it depends.

This slide illustrates
two divergent trends

in state level legislation
and policy making on gender.
In the blue states, the trend is toward
a more expansive view of gender.

Since 2017, these states have
been busy adopting policies
that allow any person to go to the DMV

and get a driver's license
that has an X on it

for the sex designation,
rather than an M or an F.

This policy move builds
on 50 years of work
by transgender rights advocates,

who've made it easier
to change ID documents
from male to female, or vice versa.
The idea behind this move is that
whatever's on your license

ought to reflect your
current gender identity,

and adding an X is
consistent with that idea.

More than just identity
documents, in the blue states,

and also some of the other
states on this slide too,

there is a right to be
free from discrimination
on the basis of gender identity

in employment and other
domains of social life.
Gender identity is usually defined broadly

in ways that include
transgender, non-binary,
and gender nonconforming individuals.

For example, here's New
York state's definition:
Gender identity means a person's actual

or perceived gender related
identity, appearance, behavior,

expression, or other gender
related characteristics,

regardless of the sex assigned
to that person at birth,
including but not limited to
the status of being transgender.
In addition to prohibiting discrimination

in forms like firing
or not hiring a person,
these laws also forbid harassment
on the basis of gender identity.

I don't mean to imply these
rules are well enforced,
and there's no harassment
or discrimination in the blue states,
that's definitely not true,

but these rules do set
norms that shape behavior,
and promote a particular set of values
with respect to sex and gender.
One such value is autonomy,
the idea that government entities

and employers shouldn't
be able to tell a person
how to look, act, or live their life,

based on the sex that that
person was assigned at birth.
Another value is equality,
the idea that being transgender

or non-binary is just another
normal human variation,

and transgender and non-binary
people should be treated
as full and equal participants
in social political and economic life.

There are still barriers to
full inclusion in these places,

but in these states, at least,
governments are thinking
about how to take down those barriers.
The red states by contrast are legislating
a very different set of values.
In 2020, Idaho enacted the first

of 15 state laws categorically
excluding transgender women
and girls from women and girl's sports.

These laws sometimes
purport to be about fairness

to cisgender women,
but a quick read proves
that that's not what they're about.

For example, many of them
apply to kids in kindergarten,

kids at an age where there are
no documented sex differences

in athletic ability that
would really matter.
Worse than that, three states
have recently passed laws barring minors

from accessing puberty
blockers and other forms
of healthcare that would affirm gender,
forms of healthcare endorsed

by every major American
medical association.
Two states have passed new bathroom bills.

Legislators admit that
these laws are motivated

by the desire to enforce a
certain set of assumptions
about what they call biological sex.
On their view, biological sex is binary,
it's either male or female,
it's fixed at birth and can't be changed,
and it's an objective phenomenon,
different from gender identity,
which is subjective and untrustworthy.

On these assumptions, being
trans or non-binary is deviant,

and questionable, and can
be the basis for exclusion.

Non-binary gender recognition
is just a non-starter
in these places.
In fact, in legislative debates,

they bring up non-binary
gender as a sort of boogeyman.

What's going to happen if we
go down the slippery slope
of respecting gender identity?
Just a few weeks ago,
Oklahoma passed the first law
that bans any kind of policy

that would put non-binary
gender on identity documents.

So we have dramatic
polarization on gender.

On this issue, as with
reproductive rights,

the people who suffer are
the ones also marginalized
by race, class, disability, childhood,
old age, and other dynamics.

Those who can't just get
up and move to blue states,

and who don't have other
privileges that insulate them
from the worst harms of discrimination.
So if we care about this, what do we do?
Well, one option is the court.
In particular, the Supreme Court.

It can overrule state laws,
and sometimes it does that.

So Obergefell versus
Hodges, that's an example,
the 2015 marriage equality decision.
Another example is a 2020 decision,
called Bostock versus Clayton County,
in which the Supreme Court held

that employment discrimination
is not permitted

against gay men, lesbians,
or transgender men and women.

But I think the leaked Roe
versus Wade opinion makes clear,
we can't rely on the Supreme Court
to ensure gender justice.

A broad historical view
of the US courts reveals

that they are the
paradigmatic master's tools,
structurally inclined
to reinforce existing power arrangements
with counterexamples like Brown v. Board,

Roe v. Wade, and Obergefell
being exceptions to the rule.

If you read Obergefell
closely, you find out
it's more about the importance of marriage

than it is about the
importance of equality.
And the Bostock case, unfortunately,

is very much about the
literal words of the law.
It doesn't invoke many values,
and there's still debate over

whether it covers bisexuality,
non-binary gender,
restrooms, sports, or healthcare.
Both Obergefell and Bostock were decided

before conservatives became
the six to three majority
on the Supreme Court that they are today,

which is the culmination
of decades of work
by the conservative legal movement

to put radically ideological
conservative judges
on the Court, not just to overrule Roe,

but also to pursue an agenda
of aggressive dismantling

of the federal government's
ability to regulate business,

while at the same time allowing
governments at all levels

to reinforce traditional social
norms and religious beliefs.
So, we can't rely on the Court.
Another master's tool, corporate America.

Corporate America can
boycott regressive states

that are passing laws to
enforce their particular vision
of biological gender.

This happened in 2016
when North Carolina passed
the first ever bathroom bill,
which then it repealed a year after,

as a result of boycotts,
notably the NBA's decision

to pull the 2017 All Star
game out of North Carolina.

But where is corporate
America this time around?

We haven't seen red state
boycotts, I've been wondering why.
According to preliminary research
from political theorist, Joanna Wuest,
who's been studying corporate protests

against state level
anti-transgender legislation,

these types of boycotts
are unlikely to occur
when multiple states pass versions
of the same legislation all at once.
I'm a person who lives in Nashville,
business is booming in Nashville.

We've got Oracle and Amazon
building new campuses,
despite the fact that the state passed

a record five bills last year
targeting the LGBTQ community.

Amazon reportedly is
offering all of its employees
up to $4,000 a year to go get abortions

or gender affirming
healthcare out of state.
So what then?
I think even if tools like litigation

and corporate pressure
are limited strategies,

the potential upsides are still
greater than the downsides.

It's true, the Supreme
Court's a big threat

to gender justice, but
it's important to recognize

the Supreme Court takes only
a tiny fraction of all cases,
and there are still many good judges

on the lower federal courts
and in the state courts.
One thing people don't realize is
that over the last five years,
transgender and non-binary litigants
have been winning a ton of cases.
One example is Gavin Grimm,

a transgender young
man who sued his school

for refusing to let him
use the boy's restroom.
He won his case in a big opinion
by the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals,
which is the court just one step down
from the Supreme Court.

And then the Supreme Court
declined to take the case,

which means that Grimm's victory
stands, at least for now.
Another example is Becky Pepper Jackson,
an 11 year old transgender girl
who sued to challenge a West Virginia law

that would've excluded her
from playing girl's sports.
She won a preliminary victory,

allowing her to play while
the case goes to trial.

An example of litigation
brought by a non-binary person

is Dana Zzyym's case against
the State Department,

for refusing to issue them
a passport with an X on it.
Zzyym argued the State Department's policy
was just plain irrational,
and so it violated federal law.
Courts sort of agreed with that,
but they weren't quite sure,
and while Zzyym's case was pending,
it took many, many years,
the Biden administration came in,
and decided they would change the policy.
Now people can get an X instead of
an M or an F on their passport.
Reading these cases,

and all the other many
cases brought by transgender

and non-binary people over
the last several decades,
one thing that really impresses me is
how often a judge will admit,
hey, I started out not knowing anything

about transgender people,
and then I learned about it

from the stories I heard in
the courtroom, in the briefs,
and then the judges come to see

how exclusion violates our
Constitution's guarantee

of equal protection, as
well as federal statutes

that forbid discrimination
on the basis of sex.
Most judges still think
that their professional role requires

that they use legal
reasoning to decide cases,
not impose their own preferences,

and sometimes you can make
a strong legal argument

that will persuade a judge
to set aside politics.
Some say if we work through the courts,

we only legitimize what's
fundamentally an unfair system,

and we draw attention away
from the more radical changes
that we need to our democracy.
I think this is a false choice.

Social movements can
work on multiple fronts
at the same time.
I think we can advocate reforms

that would take power away
from the Supreme Court,
like term limits, or adding more Justices,
while also pursuing lawsuits to put a stop
to laws that target transgender children.
I also think the relationship

between litigation and
politics is more complicated,
and harder to predict than people

who make these trade
off arguments imagine.
So sure it's possible,

the Supreme Court's going
to reverse all the progress

that transgender and
non-binary people have made.

The court could even decide
it's going to reconsider

marriage equality after it
gets done eviscerating Roe.

But sometimes losses in court
can spur political change,
by mobilizing social movements,

a phenomenon that legal
scholar, Doug NeJaime,
calls winning through losing.

That's what the conservative
legal movement did.
They used the Roe versus Wade decision

to mobilize political support
for the pro-life cause,
and that's something I hope
the other side will try to do now.
In this moment, I wish we'd all
be thinking broader questions,

asking, why isn't reproductive
justice in our Constitution?

Why isn't gender justice
in the Constitution?
Why aren't they explicitly there?

The Equal Rights Amendment
was defeated in the 1970s
for reasons including the fears

that it would lead to
gay rights, abortion,
and government funded daycare.
I think those would be great things.
Those are things we ought to have
in a Constitutional democracy in 2022.

This would be a big change,
amending the Constitution,
not a short term project.
It'd be a generational struggle.
I would like to see that struggle,

but I'd hate to see
people abandon smaller,
more incremental projects on the theory
that things have to get so much more worse
before they can get better.

To borrow an idea from
another legal scholar,
Dorothy Roberts, I think we should ask
whether the reforms that we want
are reformist or non-reformist.
So her question would be,

what kind of a world does this
reform help us to imagine?
Does it help us to imagine a world
of radical gender autonomy and equality?
Or does it constrain our imaginations?

I think there's a lot of
incremental litigation

that can help us move
towards radical change.

As for business, maybe
boycotts aren't on the table,
but corporations can send their lobbyists

to work behind the scenes and
persuade state legislators

not to pass the worst versions
of these anti-LGBTQ laws.
They can support the community groups
and legal organizations that are
on the ground fighting these laws,
and they can advance social change

by listening to their own
transgender, non-binary,
and gender non-conforming employees,

and adopting the supportive
and inclusive policies
that those people are asking for.
I'll conclude by underscoring,
we cannot assume that either lawyers
or employers are going to save us.
Law is fundamentally conservative,

and despite what I heard
from the earlier panel,
I am not convinced that business is
about anything other than making money.

Neither is a substitute
for organizing politically,
that's something that has to happen,
but I'm not ready to say either

that we should abandon
these master's tools.
(audience applauding)
